awd_titl_txt: Codes from Curves: Structure, Decoding, and Modern Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research into algebraic coding theory. The large volume of data generated today motivates the need for distributed storage systems which can provide long-term storage of data with highly reliable retrieval and availability of information to users. A distributed storage system consists of a network of storage nodes. A stored file may be retrieved by accessing these nodes. In such a system, individual nodes may be unreliable; for instance, they may become unavailable due to routine maintenance. For this reason, how information is stored across the network is highly relevant. The goal is to create a storage system that allows for recovery of lost data while limiting both network traffic and the number of disks accessed. This project addresses the problem by appealing to the underlying structure of a family of error-correcting codes defined using algebraic geometry. The codes have robust structure that yields powerful local properties and potential to balance storage overhead, reliability, network traffic, and repair bandwidth.  
 
This project considers the use of codes obtained via algebraic geometric constructions in highly relevant applications. The following problems will be studied: coding for distributed storage via algebraic geometric and combinatorial points of view, with the goals of minimizing node access and repair bandwidth; and explicit construction of locally correctable codes, quantum codes, and secret sharing schemes using algebraic geometric tools. Code structure will be explored, and decoding codes which are directs sum may be handled by decoding or repair within its factors. Full use will be made of the automorphism group of the code as well as natural nested structures inherited from the underlying algebraic geometry. Much of the work in this proposal is focused on algebraic geometric constructions utilized in situations where limiting network traffic in the decoding process is desirable; the aim is to accomplish this by capitalizing on the natural underlying structure of algebraic geometric codes rather than appealing exclusively to locality. In doing so, the performance guaranteed by the code construction is maintained (meaning code parameters do not suffer from local requirements) while making the codes more amenable to current applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our data-centric society drives the need for distributed storage systems that provide highly reliable and readily available access to stored information. We may consider a distributed storage system as a network of n nodes in which a stored file may be retrieved by accessing k nodes, for some kIn such a system, individual nodes can be unreliable and may become unavailable to users if they are flooded with requests, are offline for routine maintenance, or servers are damaged, making the data stored on them inaccessible (either temporarily or permanently lost). Replicating the data provides resilience but requires large storage overhead. Classical codes for error correction and erasure recovery require accessing all available nodes in the network, which is not practical. Instead, we need codes that minimize the repair bandwidth, meaning the amount of data accessed to repair one unit of data, through codes designed for linear exact repair, or that minimize node access, meaning the number of disks accessed to repair one disk, through locally correctable codes. Locally recoverable codes provide erasure recovery by accessing r nodes where r is very small in comparison to the k traditionally required whereas codes for linear exact repair recover erasures via small contributions from many nodes in the network, limiting network traffic. Codes for fractional decoding perform error correction using a fraction (less than 1) of information from the k symbols normally used. These types of codes support data accessibility in distributed environments. 

During this award, we discovered new ways to employ algebraic geometry and combinatorics to provide constructions of these locally recoverable codes, codes for linear exact repair, and codes for fractional decoding. We utilized fiber products of curves to design new families of locally recoverable codes with multiple recovery sets for each symbol. We achieve arbitrary availability through the use of maximal curves. We obtained nonvanishing rate locally recoverable codes constructed from the Hermitian and norm-trace curves by using lines through points on the curve as recovery sets and noting that some functions reduce to low-degree polynomials on lines, going beyond the traditional set of functions considered in Hermitian codes. We designed graph-based codes to protect against symbol loss from multiple erasures by using Tanner codes inherit locality and availability from their inner codes, allowing one to design longer codes with specified locality and availability and select a recovery tier based on the number and pattern of erasures. We designed linear exact repair schemes for higher rate codes which contain Reed-Muller subcodes and generalized the method to particular multivariate evaluation codes. We provided a fractional decoding algorithm for codes from the Hermitian curve, the first of its kind for codes from curves of positive characteristic. We defined multivariate Goppa codes, generalizing the classical Goppa codes used in the McEliece cryptosystem. As a byproduct, we obtain entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting codes along with families of long LCD, self-dual, and self-orthogonal codes.  
 
This award and the advances described above provided a foundation for training of undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers. The research environment supported a range of outreach activities, including math circles for middle school students.
